definitions: To misunderstand each other because each person is talking about something different without realizing it.
To have a conversation where the participants are not understanding each other's true intentions or subjects.
examples: We kept talking at cross-purposes during the meeting, so nothing got resolved.
It felt like we were talking at cross-purposes the whole time; I thought we were discussing the budget, and she was focused on staffing.
They realized they had been talking at cross-purposes for twenty minutes when they finally clarified their topics.
